review.title: Unknown Words Analysis in POS tagging of Sinhala Language
review.abstract: Part of Speech (POS) is a very vital topic in Natural Language Processing (NLP) task in any language, which involves analysing the construction of the language, behaviours and the dynamics of the language, the knowledge that could be utilized in computational linguistics analysis and automation applications. In this context, dealing with unknown words (words do not appear in the lexicon referred as unknown words) is also an important task, since growing NLP systems are used in more and more new applications. One aid of predicting lexical categories of unknown words is the use of syntactical knowledge of the language. The distinction between open class words and closed class words together with syntactical features of the language used in this research to predict lexical categories of unknown words in the tagging process. An experiment is performed to investigate the ability of the approach to parse unknown words using syntactical knowledge without human intervention. This experiment shows that the performance of the tagging process is enhanced when word class distinction is used together with syntactic rules to parse sentences containing unknown words in Sinhala language.

sections.text: In this context, dealing with unknown words (words that do not appear in the lexicon) is also an important task, as growing NLP systems are being used in ever new applications. A tool for predicting lexical categories of unknown words is the use of syntactic words. The distinction between open class words and closed class words is made together with syntactic features of the language used in this study to predict lexical categories in the process.

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND OF THE PROBLEM OF UNKNOWN WORDS
sections.text: The occurrence of unknown words is one of the most common problems that arise in part of the process of language tagging, i.e., the words that appear in sentences but are not included in the training corpus. New words are constantly entering the language, acronyms and proper names are very often created, and new nouns and verbs are added to the language at a surprising rate. Thus, it is impossible to train the tagger for every possible word in the language. Therefore, unknown words are not negligible in POS tagging. Thus, in order to build a full tagger, taggers must be created with some knowledge of the keyword for an unknown word. There are two approaches to treating unknown words in the language: the first approach is to construct a complete lexicon, then treat unknown words in a simple way. The second approach is to reject input. The second approach is to attempt to analyze the word at the time of encounter with a set of humanly defined rules: the first approach is to construct a complete lexicon, then treat unknown words in a simple way.

sections.heading: III. OPEN CLASS VS CLOSED CLASS WORDS
sections.text: Traditionally, the definition of POS is based on morphological and syntactical functions. Similar to most other languages, POS in Sinhalese can also be divided into two broad categories: closed classes and open classes. Closed classes are those that have relatively fixed members. Closed classes are generally function words: usually very short, common, and play an important role in grammar. In contrast, open classes are the type to which each language can include a larger number of words, and new words are constantly coined or borrowed from other languages. Words that normally contain the main content of a sentence belong to the category of open word classes. In Sinhalese, all nouns and verbs can be placed under open word classes. However, Nipatha and Upasarga behave different behavior in Sinhalaic grammar. Words belonging to Nipatha and Upasarga are not changed according to time and gender, but Upasarga always combine with nouns and provide additional (improved) meanings.

sections.text: Language analysis based on FEATURESNLP is based mainly on morphological and syntactical characteristic analysis of a language, and the availability of lexical resources is crucial for these tasks. Therefore, a corpus for a language is an important lexical resource in the field of NLP. In order to make the corpus more useful for linguistic research, they must comment with appropriate knowledge sources so that they are suitable for processing with linguistic applications. An example of the annotation of a corpus is the version of the corpus developed by the UCSC as part of the PAN Localization project in 2005, in which information about the part of the speech (verb, noun, adjective, etc.) is added to the corpus in the form of daily sentences. The corpus we use in this research is the beta version of the corpus developed by the UCSC as part of the PAN Localization project in 2005.

sections.text: In this research, we assume that every new word found in the part of the linguistic marking process of the Sinhalese language belongs to the category of open word categories, so the algorithm of the unknown word should dictate that every unknown word among all open class elements of the language elements is equally likely to be ambiguous. Subsequently, the tagger calculates the probability of the tag sequence and the maximum probability based on the text corpus and suggests the right tag. Furthermore, foreign words and numbers have been treated separately as they do not form a syntactic relationship with other language categories in the language.

sections.heading: VI. EVALUATION
sections.text: The evaluation of the system was mainly driven by training the system using the Sinhala text corpus, which consisted of 2754 sentences and 90551 words, and which contained data from newspaper articles of different genres.For the test data set, the data was carefully selected to test three different versions of the tagger.The first sentence was collected from the training corpus to test version 1 of the tagger, which consisted of 621 words known only to the system, and 36 sets. The second test set was also collected to test version 2 and 3 of the tagger.The data was drowned out of the Sinhala text corpus outside the trained dataset. The second test set consisted of 51 sentences, 1024 words. Of 1024 words, 171 words were unknown to the system. To evaluate the performance of the tagger, two gold standard test sets were created.

sections.heading: VII. RESULT AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: The performance of the tagger was measured using three different versions of progressively improved tagging mechanisms. Version 1 is the simplest form of the tagger that works only with known words that reject all unknown words as tagging errors. Version 2 is a slightly updated version that treats all unknown words as nouns and suggests NNN to any new word that occurs in the tagging process. Version 3 is the full version of the tagger that uses statistical techniques to guess the best tag for unknown words by taking into account the context of the surrounding words.Table VI shows the performance of our system for these three different versions of tagging mechanisms, and the experiment confirms the effectiveness of our unknown word-guessing techniques. As the performance of each tagging approach shows, version 2 shows a decrease in accuracy compared to the other two versions. This shows that the approach followed in version 2 when guessing parts of speech for unknown words is not a reliable method for the Sinhalal language version, which shows that most of the IV is divided between 1.950% accuracy for most of the words.

sections.heading: PERFORMANCE OF THE TAGGER
sections.text: However, the overall accuracy of the tagger has shown that the distinction between closed class and open class word categories is a powerful tool for handling unknown words for the Sinhalese language. However, tagging accuracy is still close to 92%, and this shows that more work needs to be done to refine the accuracy of the tagger. Therefore, the tagger can be recommended to improve its handling of unknown words. Mainly, morphological recognition can also be helpful in predicting possible language parts for many unknown words. Therefore, the overall performance of the tagger can be improved by using a hybrid approach, with the system gaining more knowledge through a set of handwritten rules. To ensure that this approach is more accurate, the results generated by the system need to be manually verified and the tagger retrained to ensure that the word is correctly tagged later.

sections.heading: VIII. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we have described two types of methods for handling unknown words in the POS marking of the Sinhalese language: The application of the methods in the Hidden Markov model based part of the approach to language marking (which we have already developed [1]) was evaluated and the results presented; implementation was tested on 90551 words, 2754 sentences of the Sinhalese text corpus and showed an accuracy of 91.5% in the tagging process of predicting tags to unknown words. Thus, the performance of the tagger proves that the distinction between closed-class and open-class words, as well as syntactical knowledge, are reliable sources of information for handling unknown words in parts of the Sinhalese language. Although this research suggested a reliable approach to handling unknown words in the POS marking, further improvements are needed to improve and optimize the algorithm. Therefore, several directions for future work are proposed here. Language-specific morphological characteristics can be helpful in predicting possible parts of the language.
